div.p: WEDNESDAY, MARCH 13, 1907.

div.head: POWER IN SYRIA
div.p: A distinguished naval officer, Lamberto Vannutelli, has recently returned from an expedition on which he was sent by the Italian Geographical Society, and has brought back interesting geographical and commercial particulars with regard to the progress which the principal nations of Europe are making in the penetration and industrial expansion of Syria and Eastern Asia Minor. New railways, lines of navigation, the large investments of European capital in commerce with the country, and the patient labours of the religious missions and of the consular agents have combined to undermine the prejudices of the East and have opened the country to the commerce and industries of all civilised people. The distinguished explorer, in an interview which he gave to the Rome "Messaggero," compares the positions of the various European nations, and points out the enormous advantages which Germany has been able to obtain by the singular and clever position which she has taken up of protectress of the Turkish Empire, which has rendered her most powerful at Constantinople. The oriental journeys of: the Emperor Williám were followed by a crowd of students, merchants, and capitalists, who mandated the Empire. German officers reorganised the army ; the firm of Krupp furnished cannon ; and thanks to the advantage of position, German capital has been employed in the most lucrative undertakings. Finally, the Deutsche Bank of Berlin, after making s. loan of 30 million marks (£1,500,000), was able to initiate the system of political railways which had its outcome in the plan for the Baghdad railway, which is the most important concession ever made by Turkey, and which, when the financial and political difficulties opposing its construction are overcome,? will form an all-powerful factor for the development of German interests in Asiatic Turkey. France, also, says Signor Vannutelli, has still-a very important position partly due to her religious protectorate. Her very numerous religious missions and schools, 'the great medical university of Beirut, and the numerOus consulates established everywhere, even in the interior, are all centres of French in. Buence and sympathy, while her important commercial undertakings, such as coal mines, railways, and ports, are supported by the inVestment of the enormous capital of two miljards of francs (£8,000,000). Notwithstand. during all this, the great extension of German influence has been greatly to the detriment of French interests, and French commerce has diminished until it now represents only 9.36 mer cent. of the whole. , Great Britain, with her occupation of Cyprus and Egypt, has a dominating position in the Mediterranean and the Persian Gulf, and from commercial point of view accounts for 38.60 ent of imports. 'I thanks to her consular serFice, the constant visits of her warships, even the smallest ports of the coast, and her immense influence in the Persian Gulf, she may be said to hold her own against the German invasion ; and thanks also to the im the importance which she gives to the shortest route between Europe and India, to the valuable commercial enterprise which she undertakes, ach as mineral works and the service of gas, water, and posts in the principal cities, she may be said to keep in touch with all that happens, and to be the preponderating political fluence in the country.

div.head: The Cairo Estates,
div.p: The issue of this company will take place in the course of next week.

div.head: New Alexandrian Paper.
div.p: A new Italian daily newspaper is to appear. shortly at Alexandria. The promoter is M. d Pompeo, of the "Imparziale."

div.head: The Brindisi Mall.
div.p: The mail from Europe, via Brindisi and Por Said. arrived at Alexandria this afternoon ang will be distributed at the G. P. O. about 4.30 p.m.

div.head: Khedivial Law School.
div.p: Sir John Scott's prize for the first and second graduates of the Khedivial Law School, Cairo has been awarded this year to Mohamed EA Hamdi and Mohamed Ef Labib Attieh.

div.head: The Ports of Egypt.
div.p: The Statistical Department of the Finance Ministry has issued a quarterly return of the navigation in the ports of Egypt and the Suez Canal. It embraces the fourth quarter of 1906.

div.head: Model-Workshops.
div.p: The Model Workshops at Cairo have been transferred from the control of the Ministry of Public Works to the Agricultural and Industrial Department of Public Instruction under Mr Wells.

div.head: Travelling Requisites.
div.p: Messrs. Walker & Meimarachi, Limited, Old Bourse Palace, Alexandria, are making a special display of travelling requisites, in the shape of trunks, portmanteaux, bags, deck chairs, etc. (Advt.]

div.head: New German Church.
div.p: The new German Evangelical Church for Cairo is to be built at Boulac, and the foundation stone will be laid on the 22nd inst. Dr. Dreyender, private chaplain to the Kaiser, is coming to Egypt to attend the ceremony.

div.head: British Chamber of Commerce.
div.p: The Mørch journal of the British Chamber of Commerce of Egypt has just made its appearance The contents include the réport of the annual meeting of the Chamber and the usual information published in the journal.

div.head: Cairo Traffic.
div.p: The Cairo police issued 354 summonses last month for misdemeanour in regard to traffic. 298 animals were taken in charge during February and kept until restored to health, their owners paying the expenses.61 summonses were issued for brutality to animals.

div.head: Concert.
div.p: This evening Mr. Leonida Photius, the well known Athenian tenor, will give a concert at the New Khedivial Hotel at Alexandria. He will be assisted by Mr. Mario Mirès, of Milan, and Mr Willy Brockhnisen, of Milan. Miss Helen Philipakis and Miss Helen Seretidon will also take part in the concert.

div.head: The Late Felix Suares.
div.p: The unveiling of the bust of the late M. Felix Suarès erected at the Umberto I. Hospital, Cairo, will take place on Sunday afternoon in the presence of the members of the deceased philanthropist, the Italian Diplomatic Agent, the staff of the consulate, members of the Italian Benevolent Society, representatives of the Press, and subscribers.

div.head: British Club.
div.p: A musical entertainment to the members and their lady friends will be given at the British Club on Saturday next, commencing at 9 p.m. Mrs. Edward Moss and Mrs. W. F. Sarjeant bave kindly consented to take part in the programme, which will also include items by Messrs. W. F. Sarjeant, F. Dudwell, Nichols, Sheldrick, and the "Osiris" glee party. In view of the great success which attended the last concert at the club, those intending to be present would be well advised to secure their seats early.

div.head: Papyrus and Chronology.
div.p: The precise date of another important historical event has just been decided by means of an Egyptian papyrus. This is the correct year in which occurred the battle of Chryso polis, and the final victory of Constantine over Licenius. A small board of Greek papyri from Theadelphia, in the Fayoum, now preserved in the Cairo Museum, bave afforded the necessary evidence upon the matter and prove that the events referred to took place in A.D. 324. The decisive document is merely a receipt for payment for some purple. But it settles a debated chronological question definitively.

div.head:
THE VILLAGE TRAGEDY.
ANOTHER VERSION.
div.p: It appears that the version at first circulated of the regrettable shooting incident at Warak, in which M. Grandmoulin is implicated, was not correct.

The circumstances are now said to be as follows. M. Grandmoulin was returning from a shooting excursion accompanied by a native boy who carried his cartridge bag. He was walking along with his gun on his shoulder and holding his bicycle in one hand, the boy followed behind, when shortly afterwards another boy of 13 came up and wanted to carry part of the load in order to share in the recompense. The first boy naturally objected and a dispute arose. M. Grandmoulin, still holding his bicycle; turned round to put an end to the dispute, when by some means or other his g'n was discharged and the second boy received a fatal wound

The "Lewa" publishes a letter from the head of the ghaffirs of the locality, stating that M. Grandmoulin had deliberately shot the boy, in order to avenge himself for some trouble he had had with the Egyptian Government. The publication of such a ridiculous assertion by the "Lewa" only proves that, despite all its protestations, our Nationalist contemporary never lets an occasion slip of displaying its xenophobia

div.head: TURKISH TRANSPORTS.
div.p: de Suez, Tuesday.

The Turkish troopship Tail, which entered the Canal yesterday afternoon, had on board 1,500 time expired troops from Hodeidah. The men mutinied owing to their being short of rations. The other troopship Hodeidah is still lying in the Suez roads guarded by a steam launch with armed coastguards aboard. She will enter the Canal as soon as the Canal dues are settled.

div.head: MINISTRY OF EDUCATION.
div.p: Saad Pasha Zaghloul arrived at Mansourah on Saturday evening and was received by the Moudir and a number of local notables at the station His Excellency passed Sunday in visiting schools at Mit Ghəmr and Simballawein and left on Monday for an inspecting tour at Damiętta and Faraskour.

Apropos of Saad Pasha Zaghlowl's speech at the General Assembly "Al Mimbar" remarks: "Which of the Minister's declarations are we to accept, that instruction in a foreign language is one of the chief needs of the country,—if in that case his preoccupation in favour of substituting the national language for Engli-h must turn out fatally-or that he hoped for instruction in Arabic on account of its utility ?..... Saad Pasha states that the pupils of the Government schools are very weak in foreign languages, but he certainly does not realise the causes of their weakness. In any case it has no relation whatever with instruction in Arabic."

Our contemporary has hardly, in our opinion, done justice to Saad Pasha's main thesis, viz. that till teachers and textbooks could be provided any sudden adoption of Arabic as the sole medium of instruction would cause the greatest confusion and disorder in the work of the Department.

div.head: KOUBBEH GARDEN CITY.
div.p: The Egyptian Enterprise & Development Company intend to create a new filial company under the designation of the Koubbeh Garden City. The capital will be L.E. 300,000 En 30,000 shares of L.E. 10 each. The object of this new company is the exploration of 115 feddańs which have been purchased from the Buburban Company:

div.head: AUTO-GARAGE AND AUTO-CABS COMPANY.
div.p: We beg to draw the attention of our readers to the prospectus of this interesting new company which appears on page 5 of to-day's issue Its capital is very moderate and the business of the vendor, M. Loukaitis, is well-known in Cairo as a satisfactory concern.

div.head: A. L. M. & D. S.
div.p: The concert given under the auspices of the above society at Lifonti's concert saloon on Friday last was voted by all present to be a decided success in every way. There were several new faces amongst those who kindly contributed towards the evening's entertainment, and we were also delighted to again see some of our old friends. The concert was undoubtedly one of the most enjoyable over given by the A.L.M. and D.S, and it is to be hoped that with all the talent that was manifested the society may continue in existence for some time to come The programme consisted of piano solos by Miss Clarke-Horsfall, duets and trios by Misses Gemma, Giorgina, and Alice Fiteni, violin soloe by Mr W.J. Hay, songs by Mesdames Fred Cree and .W.F. Sarjeant and Messrs. G. Fergusson. L.A. Johnson, J.A F. Purvis, and W.F Sarjeant, ending with the vocal duet, "Watchman, what of the night?" by Messrs. J.A.F. Purvis and W.F. Sarjeant. The various songs, etc., were accompanied by Mesdames Bulman, Fred Cree, ManGavin, and
W.F. Sarjeant, and Mr. R. Brown The thanks of those present are due to all who kindly took part, and it is hoped that other similar concerts will be given in the near future.

div.head: SUCCESSFUL CHARITY CONCERT:·
div.p: A very successful concert took place at the Winter Palace Hotel on Saturday evening, in aid of the Luxor Hospital for Natives The friends who kindly interested themselves in organising the entertainment worked hard for its success, and they must have been gratified at the result of their efforts, for not only was a most enjoyable evening spent, but the very creditable sum of £29 109. was obtained for the charity, nearly £4 of this being handed in by the ladies who offered their services as programme sellers.

The manager, M. Schalch, always ready to further a good cause, had converted the spacious lounge into a perfect concert hall, with an improvised platform decorated with palms, and at 9 o'clock to the minute the proceedings began.

The promoters were most fortunate in obtaining to help of such clever amateurs, and especially in enlisting the sympathy of Fraulein Terese Schnackenburg, a lady whose vocal talents are of a very high order indeed, and who charmed her hearers by singing two extra songs besides those on the programme, all rendered with a style and finish that one has not often the good fortune to hear in this country.

The pianoforte playing of Mr. Ewart was also a great treat, while Miss Allen's fine and sympathetic voice was greatly appreciated, and it is to the energy and talents of this lady, that the success of the concert is in a great measure owing. Space fails to mention individually each performer, but the entire programme was, as the chairman (the Rev. G F. Sams) put it, on an unusually high level, and the last notes of the graceful "Lullaby" song by Miss Allen in response to an encore, were heard with regret by all. The concert was honoured by the presence of H.R.H Prince Freidrick Wilhelm of Prussia, and amongst others who took tickets (nearly all of whom might be seen in the audience) were : Count Schulenburg, Freihen von Kuyphausen, the Earl and Countess of Carnarvon, Sir. Charles Cust, Count and Countess Lichtenfelde, Graf Edler von der Planitz, Mme Fräuhel, Countess Skannisky, Mme Klobukowski, M. Valdrôme, Lady Ewart and party, Mr. and Mrs.Mappin, Mr. and Mrs. Brodrick and party, Mr. and Mrs Evans Lombe, Mrs. Berners, Mrs. A. Lambert, Mr Allen and Miss B. Allen, Dr., Mrs. and Miss Crookshank, Mrs Alford, Miss Bruce, Mrs. and Miss Warner, Dr. and Mrs. Saunders, Miss Payne, Mrs. Wise, Miss Davidson, Mr. Wace, Mr Hazel Mr. Otway, Mr. Corelli, eto, eto.

The Winter Palace is still full, and is keeping up the weekly dances with much spirit. The hospital dance was a great success, resulting in a sum of over £20 ; while the Gymkhanas each Thursday are still going strong, and continue to attract large audiences, last week's meeting producing a record of 152 tickets sold at the gate, besides season tickets.

An interesting visitor who has just left for Cairo is M. Chartran, the famong French artist, and amongst other visitors still at the hotel are Lord and Lady Carnarvon, who are making quite a long stay here, Vicomte Fleury, Lord and Lady Hastings, Countess of Lanesborough and party, Prin. cess Carl von Hanan, Baron Victinghoff, and many others.
H.R.H. Prince George of Cumberland and suite are expected almost immediately on their way from Assouan.

div.head: ARRIVAL OF THE ARABIC.
div.p: The White Star liner Arabic, chartered by Mr. Frank Clark for a Mediterranean cruise, arrived at Alexandria this morning from Jaffa with over 500 American tourists on board They left for Cairo by two special trains at 9.30 and 11 a.m respectively.

div.head: CLASSICAL CONCERT.
div.p: Mlles Vera and Nadesda Chernetzka have already achieved no inconsiderable success during their tours in Russia and other European countries ; and their début before a Cairo audience on Monday evening at the Savoy will ensure an enthusiastic reception at their future appearances. They are certainly gifted with an immense natural power ; and if their performances are somewhat lacking in delicacy and refinement the fault is one which doubtless experience will rectify. Thus in Mlle.

Vera's rendering of Bach's Orgue Toccata and - Fugue, though her execution was brilliant, she was very much inclined to force expression by too much pedalțing However, in several of her later items she displayed a really admirable feeling, and restraint. She is undoubtedly a remarkably fine pianist, and her treatment of Tschaikowski's "Paraphrase" was received with all the enthusiasm it deserved.

Mlle. Nadesda Chervetzka is the 'fortunate possessor of a contralto voice of great power and compass ; and we look forward to hearing her again under better acoustic conditions She has an intensely dramatic instinct, but like her sister is inclined rather to force her effects. She was heard at her best in Taskin's "Les Cloches" and Rubinstein's "Pandero," and her rendering of the "Habanera" song from
Carmen" was also excellent. Her natural voice is so magnificent that we only regret that she has not been able to devote more time to perfooting its production.

div.head:
CHARITY BAZAAR.
TO BE OPENED BY LADY CROMER.
div.p: The bazaar in aid of the funds for "L'Amie de la Jeune Fille," which is to be held at the Continental Hotel on Saturday, promises to be a very great success. The Countess of Cromer has graciously consented to be present and to open the bazaar at 3 o'clock, and many. of the leading ladies and residents have promised their support to the undertaking. Many of the leading shops have generously given valuable additions to the various stalls, at which will al-o be found delightful articles of all sorts which have been contributed by those who are interested in the good work. There will be stalls for perfumery and articles of the toilette, for needlework for flowers, for oriental decorations, for dainty linen goods, cushions, sachets and the like, for dolls, and for cigarettes and wine. There will also be a fishpond and a substantial buffet, which latter will be served by the management of the Continental Hotel. The room in which the bazaar will be held will be charmingly decorated, the Maison Colombo having offered to 8 10w its appreciation of the work in this manner, and music will also be supplied throughout the afternoon.

Amongst those who have contributed such substantial support to the undertaking are the Maisons Weinrich, Grenato, France's, du Progres, Cente Mille Articles, Colombo, Librairie Kaer, Madkour Hasoun, Kruger, Constantinides, Pharmacie Savoy, Carlo Gila, J. Hornstein, Mayer, Stein, Sussmann, Sesti, Lafergue, Brachet, Privat, 0. Chimchidian, J. Cohen, Huges, Librairie Cordier, &c, &c. Donations, monetary and otherwise, have also been given by the following >.

In addition to these mention must also be made of the advertisements, posters, and circulars in connection with the work and the bazaar which have been given by Mr. Press.

div.head: TENNIS TOURNAMENT.
div.p: The big tournament this year has been, as usual, most successful and popular. The entries were larger than last year, and in spite of the three new courts the tournament has taken longer than last year to play off. A large gathering Assembled yesterday to witness the finals.

The play of the ladies in the finals and semifinals was of a very high standard, and we witnessed some excellent matches. The Tennis Committee, and especially Mr. C. A. "Mackintosh, may be congratulated on their excellent arrangements and general organization of the tournament.
The Countess of Cromer very kindly gave away the prizes

div.head: STEAMER MOVEMENTS.
div.p: The Moss liner Seti sailed from Malta yesterday afternoon and is due here on Saturday next, at daybreak, with passengers, mails and general cargo.
The S.S. Egyptian Prince, with passengers and general cargo, "left Manchester yesterday end is due at Alexandria on or about the 28th inst.
The 9.9. Moorish Prince, with passengers end general cargo, left Malta on Monday, and is dao at Alexandria on Friday.

div.head:
KHEDIVIAL OPERA HOUSE."
"HERODIADE."
div.p: "Hérodiade" is undoubtedly a fine opera, whatever one may think of the story. Massenet shows real strength, beauty, and what one may call an appropriate spirit throughout ; at some momeðts perhaps he is above himself. In the Temple scene, for example, the m sic for the palm dance has á stern rhythm and set purpose that the great old writers themselves might not have disowned Herod's theme throughout is passionate, strong, wilful : Hérodiade's appeal to him, "Ne me refuse pas-rappelle-toi," has great beauty ; and the love duet in the cavern is a splendid episode of passion and purity meeting. That duet is certainly incongruous to the story. John the Baptist is too human, almost "feministe," M. Massenet himself, it might be, in a moment of religious fervour ; and Salomé seems too innocent, too ready to be a convert: Oscar Wilde's idea is surely more logical--the passionate oriental who loves the ascetic, dead or alive,' with the fullest, most sensuous desire.

The orchestra again was (as in "La Reine Fiamette") really excellent, and M. Archimbault in thorough harmony with it, and with his singers. It was curious, though, and revealing to note how the one singer to whom he did not have to devote strenuous attention was Mme Chaix-Bonheur. Whatever one may say of her voice, as a voice, sher use of it is superb ; ber rendering of the appeal to the Fetrarch was beyond praise for its subtlety and suppressed passion. Really one has to recant one's personal taste and forget everything in admiration of her ert. M. Mezy as Herod was also excellent; he, too, showed real subtlety in "Salomé, Salomé," though it was his high notes, and not his delicacy, that moved the house Mme Baron, though she looked charming and acted well, was not at all satisfactory, and her voice gave & more unfavourable impression than usual : subdued effects evidently are beyond her. M. Maas was dignified and accurate throughout. M.M. Gurdin and Chappelon as Vitellius and the High Priest were fair, but their voices are thin and not very pleasing. M. Escalais showed, as John the Baptist, what he really can do with a part that hardly suits him musically, that is, for his acting was most excellent. He, like Mme Baron, had to rely on low notes and subdued effects, but unlike her, he was always accurate, and pronounced, and even in his most restrained moments his voice had real depth and beauty and distinction standing out amid all the rest. He proved himself the fine singer he certainly is, and for merit of interpretation and musicianship he and Mme Chaix Bunheur undoubtedly carried off the honours : and perhaps on the whole performance we may place M. Mézy next. In the final dance-here the opera leaves the tradition entirely, as the head of the prophet is the last thing Salomé desires!-Mlle Deliny looked most charming, and really danced gracefully. It is a fine opera, and on the whole can be said to have been finely given.

div.head: THE OPERA HOUSE STRIKE:
div.p: The members of the chorus of the Khedivial Opera House were convoked yesterday morning at the French Consulate in order to receive the remainder of their emoluments. Nearly all of them refused to accept what was offered them by M. Poncet, for the reason that for the months of December And January they were paid at the rate of 30 days a month, but their impresario wishes to benefit by the two; days less in February!

div.head: ZIZINIA THEATRE.
div.p: To anyone in search of sudden hot and cold changes, we should recommend the French operetta company now playing at the Zizinia Theatre. There is an incompleteness and want of stability about their productions which is truly bewildering ; one finds oneself applauding and almost simultaneously wondering what there is to applaud. The reason probably is that the solog, well enough sung on the whole, are spoilt by a palpably untrained chorus and an orchestra lamentably out of time. It is disheartening to think that the many and vigorous rehearsals, which are necessary to remedy these defects, are probably without the range of possibility for a touring company giving a different operetta every night of their week's stay. Therefore we must not be too exacting. All the same our pleasure is seriously impaired at hearing Lecocq's and Messager's well-known airs given with such a want of swing andaccoracy. This, we have said, applies mainly to the chorus, for there is plenty of good material amongst the principals. Mlle Delormes sings and acts very vivaciously, at times alınost to excess. Mlles Hilbert and GillBerthe and Mme Degoyou are all satisfactory in their way, while Mlle de Kiercour sings very. prettily and is delightfully mignonne. MM. Torin and Lazairie work hard and to good effect. The former's Florestan in "Véronique" was most successful, while M Moret made a decided hit as Seraphin in the same piece. Besides this, there have been given "Le Petit Doo," "Le Jour et la Nuit," end "Les Mousquetaires au Couvent." The order of merit is also that of production.

There is still much to be hoped from the remainder of the repertoire, which includes amongst others "La Fille de Mme Angot. "La Grande Duchesse," "Les Cloches de Corneville," and for these the troupe should certainly draw good houses.

div.head: PERSONAL AND SOCIAL.
div.p: The Earl and Countess of Meath are staying at the New Victoria Hotel, Ramleh. They will leave Port Said on the 8th proxo., probably by the P. & S.S. Caledonia. ..

There are surely no more energetic peer or peeress than Lord and Lady Meath, and. Lady Meath's generous philanthropy is well-known in Egypt, where she has done much for the poor and the blind, especially in Alexandria. Lord Meath is perhaps most keen on open spaces-indeed, Lord Rosebery once said, "If Meath had his way, he would pull down the whole of London to make a garden of it for its' inhabitants !" He invented Empire Day.; is very keen on teaching.the young idea, not only how to shoot, but also how to drill; and is the active president of that remarkable organisation, the Church Army. Lord Meath was at · Eton as a boy, and he remembers the arrival of the late Empress Frederick and her husband at Windsor. He helped to drag her carriage up the Castle hill when he should have been otherwise engaged, and this involved a somewhat painful interview with the headmaster, the result being that in after years Lord Meath was able to inform her Majesty that he had shed his blood for her sake! After leaving Eton he had some glorious times in the little Principality of Schaumberg-Lippe, where he went to learn German. In company with some | other choice young English spirits, he organised a paperchase; so little was this game understood by the natives, that when the field asked. some peasants whether they had seen the hare, they replied, "Ah, yes, the thiet has the bouty in a bag ; you will catch him over the hill." Next day a policeman came from the Prince of Schaumberg-Lippe, his Highness having heard that the boys had been robbed of five hundred thalers. Prolonged explanation only drew from thë policeman the remark, "Good heavens ! the English are all mad."

Lady Meath, who is & cousin of Lord Lauderdale's, specialises in rather more definitely charitable schemes. Perhaps one of her best ideas is to give the old and infirm people in -workhouses something to do. Moreover, when she was Lady Brabuzon she started the Ministering Children's League, the members of which are pledged to do at least one kind deed every day: Lady Meath also finds time to be an enthusiastic gardener at Kilruddery, her husband's beautiful place in Co. Wicklow. A good story, by the way, is told of this property. Although Lord · Meath is most generous in throwing it open to the public, there are some days in the year on which it has to be closed to preserve the private ownership On one of these days an American visitor, finding his way barred, and being informed that it was Lord Meath's property, anxiously inquired whether the sea also belonged to his ļordship, as he desired to bathe, and yet did not want to trespass.

Fakhry Pasha, Minister of Public Works, will give a banquet of 100 covers on the 21st inst, at the Savoy Hotel, Cairo, to a number of Government officials and the members of the Diplomatic Corps in the Capital
Count and Countess von Bernsdorff, who have gone to Berlin on account of the illness of a relation, will return to the German Agency, at Cairo, about the 17th inst.

Sir John Harrington, British Minister to the Court of Abyssinia, arrived in Cairo from England on Saturday last. After a stay of ten days in Cairo Sir John Harrington will proceed on his way to Addis Abeba.

Admiral Sir Arthur Wilson, V.C., who has been appointed Admira' of the Fleet on retirement from active service, gained the Victoria Cross by a notable act of bravery at El Teb, where he was present with the naval brigade, Sir Redvers Buller described his act as "one of the most courageous he has ever witnessed." There was a gap in the square, and five or six of the enemy, seeing it, rushed forward, | attempting to pierce the ranks. Then Captain Wilson advanced to meet them alone, and breaking his sword in his effort to cut one of them down, would not retire a step, but held his ground, knocking them down with his fists. Either by a miracle or the surprising nature of his attack, he escaped with a few wounds, and the square closing up rescued him. He was. presented with a sword by the torpedo officers of the torpedo school-ship Verdon, in admiration of his gallantry,

Sir William Willcocks, after leaving Gondo.. koro, proceeded to Lake Victoria Nyanza and, we are sorry to hear arrived, at Kampala seriously ill with malarial fever. According to the latest news he is lying there in the house of a medical missionary and all that is possible is being done. Lady Willcocks left Suez før Mombasa yesterday in order to join her husband. Sir William's condition is grave, but he is progressing as well as can be expected,
M. Bourgueil, the new judge of the Cairo Mixed Courts, is leaving Marseilles for Alex. andria on the 14th inst, in order to take over his new duties.

The passengers by the train de luxá for Upper Egypt last night were Mme. Devereuse, Mr. A. G. Cox, Mr. Simon, Mr. Urquhart, Mr. Horschitz, Mr. Peter, Count Valesky, Mr. Gray and party, Mr. and Mrs. Ozman,

div.head:
TERRIBLE EXPLOSION BATTLESHIP BLOWN UP.
EXTRAORDINARY EFFECTS

div.p: PARIS, March - A compressed air torpedo burst on the French battleship Jena, lying at T. exploding the magazine. A large complement of the crew were on board. It is feared serious catastrophe has occurred.
Admiral Bienaimé announced in the ber of Deputies that it was feared that were 400 victims.
(Reuter)
The Jena has been flooded and there fear of further explosions. There were 690 on board at the time of the disaster. Ad Manceron was wounded.
The stern of the Jena was blown out, of the officers and men were able to themselves. The injured, many of whom frightfully burned, are being remover hospital.
(Reuter)
The explosion of a compressed air to has blown up the powder stores of the Adm battleship Jena. There are said to be 2 300 victims,

M. Thomson, Minister of Marine, has for Toulon, *** The latest news received at the Min of Marine states that the number of those have disappeared on board the Jena is high. Seven officers are among them. I believed that a large number of the k succumbed to asphyxia. The injured nu 40. The magazines have been flooded. A. of a projectile killed a child of two yea the suburbs. si sar e

The latest official estimates minimise the casualties. It is stated that 50 men were killed, including Captain Adigard and Commander Vertier, and 100 injured, but it is impossible to say definitely till to day, when the we which is a total loss, has been brought dock and the remains of the victims recovered. The explosion, the cause of which is a mystery occasioned extraordinary scenes Seamen hurled into the air ; guns went off ; the was shrouded in dark smoke ; the arsenal buildings were set on fire ; persons were injured by shells and débris at great distances ; m were electrocuted by fused cables on the do
(Reuter)

CHAMBER OF DEPUTIES. -Yesterday's discussion resolved itself into a sharp contest between the Socialist member, M. Jaurès, M. Clemenceau. · The latter indignantly repudiated the theory put forward by M. Jau that the Government should have remained passive while Paris was in darkness, and citizens exposed to cut-throats and robbers. was to avoid this that the Government had sent military engineers to the electrical works
The newspapers' emphasize the over-widen: split between the Radicals and the Socialists
(Reuter)
M. Casimir Perier, ex-President of the Republic, is dead.
(Havas)

The death of M. Petkoff is a serious loss the country, particularly in view of the present unrest in the Balkans. M. Stancioff, the E reign Minister, assumes the Premiership. T assassin, Alexander Petroff, wag & minore official
(Reuter)

div.head:
SOUTH AFRICA.
THE LOYALTY OF THE BOERS

div.p: General Botha was entertained at a banquet by the citizens. He said that British interests were absolutely safe in the hands of the ne Cabinet, which was as zealous for the hong of the flag as any Ministry could be. The Transvaalers were deeply grateful because they had been trusted in a manner unequalled history. The Boers would never forget su generosity. The Cabinet would do its best to create a great united nation. He denied that the Government sought to cripple the mines that the Boers would combine with the mi owners to reduce the natives to servitude.
(hallas)

div.head:
JAPS IN CALIFORNIA.
QUESTION TEMPORARILY SHELVED

div.p: The Governor of California, in his message to the Assembly, says that President Roosevelt had complained to him that the action of tl Legislative Assembly in excluding Japan from the schools would have an unfortunate effect. The President's efforts would be devoted to securing the exclusion of Japanese laboure by a friendly agreement.. .
(Router)
The Legislative Assembly has decided to abstain from any action with regard to th Japanese question this session
(Reuter)

div.head: ARABIC READING BOOK.
div.p: We reviewed not long ago the first volume of this important series of the late Frederi Du Pré Thornton's Arabic books of the classical language, edited by Mr. Reynold A Nicholson, of which the work now under review is the second volume. While the first part dealt with the grammar, which is ar abridgement of Wright's famous work, the author gives in the present volume the original Arabic text of suratu'l fatiha, the first chapter of the Coran, as well as many verses of euratul a'raf and the whole of saratu' agabun, all of which are printed in very clear ype with all the correct vowels, to give the reader a fair notion of the style and contents of the Coran, followed by four stories of Arab warriors and some historical extracts relating co the Prophet Mohamed, such as the asking of Mecca and the death of the Prophet, and various other extracts, but smaller type und with less vowels han the suras, all of which are most excellent exercises for the student of Arabic, and the jook ends, or rather begins on the left side, with a grammatical analysis of the Arabic text of the suras which are extremely helpful. n this part the author gives in several columns the transliteration, meaning, grammatical analysis, Arabic names of some of the xpressions, the numbers of the sections of Ir. Thornton's grammar and the roots of most all the Arabic words. The book also contains a glossary (placed between the Arabic ait and the grammatical analysis) to the non'organic passages, of great use to the reader as he English translation of this part of the book is not given. One fault, however, we find with he analysis. It does not give the transliteration, etc., of all the text, but leaves out words and terminations which the author evidently considers too well understood to require explanation, while in our opinion it would have made that part more complete to have given the whole text. The size of the book is very convenient and we strongly recommend it to I those who wish to study that beautiful and ch language--classical Arabic.
Elementary Arabio-First Reading Book, by Frederio Pré Thornton and Reynold A. Nicholson, M. A. imbridgo. At the University Press. 1907.

div.head: EGYPTIAN LAND AND INVESTMENT.
div.p: Among the land companies of recent creation the Egyptian Iand and Investment Company is surely one of those which have been the most neglected by investors. This company was floated on the 6th December, 1904. I capital amounts to £100,000, represented 20,000 shares of five Egyptian pounds eac and 2,000 founders, shares. Its board of directors is composed of Bartau 'asha (president Khalil Pusha Khayat, Luzzato Pasha, an Messrs. Tigrane Gamsaragam, Michel Bey Re zian, Emmanuele Stross, and N. E Tamvec | who are, at the same time, the founders of the company There was no public subscription the founders distributing the shares privately It is owing to this fact that the company has attracted so little public attention and i shares have not been sought after on the Bourse.

According to the statutes, the company profits have to be divided in the following manner : 10% to the reserve fund, the necessary sum to pay a cumulative dividend of 5 to the ordinary shares, the balance to be di tributed thus : 5% to the directors, 65 % exti dividend to ordinary shareholders, and 30 to the founders' shares.

In going through the balance-sheet of the company to the 30th November last, we observe that it receipts are composed of ; profits on properties sold rents. interests received on deposits sits. Total.

The expenses amounting, only the net profits come to and according to the statutes, have been distributed in the following manner : to the ordinary shares, re presenting the cumulative 5% dividend. extra dividend of 65% the same shares on the balance. 18% to the board of directors Jarors to the Deferred shares Representing the 30% on the remaining profits.
The ordinary shares have thus received PT. 60 per share, and the Founders' shares, P.T. 110.

It is interesting to glance at the various items of the last balance sheet. On the credit side we note that the properties of the company on the 30th November were valued at L.E. 79,866, sundry debtors amounted to L.E. 28,138, the dividends on investments to L.E. 4,000, and the general expenses to L.E. 748. On the debit side we find sundry creditors for L.E. 1,486.

On comparing the above figures with those of the preceding balance sheet, we observe that Che company acquired, during 1906, new lands to the value of about £26,000 more than its Bales, as the item "Properties" in the balance sheet on the 30th Nevember, 1905, amounted only to L.E. 53,500, whereas it stood, on the Both November last, at L.E. 79,866.

The actual properties of the company are:15,846 sq are pics near the Farkha canal, at Moharrem Bey.. 7,528 square pics at Karmous, in the native quarter. 8,356 square pics, including buildings, front ing the Ramleh road, between Flem ing and Bacos 653 feddang at Awada-Baslacoum, near Kafr-el-Dawar, the cost of which is about L.E. 41 $ per feddan to-day. The company has sold during 1906 :6,869 square pics, ex-Autofage property, at the corner of Sidi-Metwalli and Salah-el-Din streets. 2,854 square pics at San Stefano. 217 feddans at El-Halafi (Gharbieh).

5 parcels of the Moharrem-Bey land We think we are right in assuming that the actual price (about £5) of the Egyptian Land and Investment Company's shares may be considered as an advantageous one, considering the undoubted increase in the price of the company's properties acquired, for the greater art, more than two years ago.

div.head: PROGRESS OF HEDJAZ RAILWAY.
div.p: This year the pilgrims coming from Damascus Medina and Mecca travelled by rail to the station of Alakhzar, 845 kilomètres south of Pamascus. They reached Tabook after a journey fone day and two nights, or thirty-six hours, and rested there for two days, for in the season of the Haj a bazaar is held at Tabook every ear. The construction of the Jaini Mosque at the place where the Prophet prayed at Tabook being pushed on with the utmost despatch. from Tabook the pilgrims again took train to lakhzar, and reached Medina after a journey my rail and road of twelve days. Before the Avent of the railway thirty days were spent in the same journey All pilgrims were carried ee of charge, rich and poor without distinction, and all pilgrims' training had a special carriage serving as a mosque, in which five daily prayers were performed regularly without stopping the trains. The Sultan has recently dered that the construction work on the line now to be started at the Medina end also, nd, in accordance with this order, survey work as already been taken in hand by the same mand several extra concessions have been granted to labourers on the line

div.head: NEW SUEZ CANAL.
PROPOSAL TO CONSTRUCT A SECO GREAT WATERWAY THROUGH EGYPT
div.p: The London correspondent of the "New York Herald" (Paris) writes : In accordance with instructions received from the Chambers of SŁ ping of the United Kingdom, the Parliament Committee of that body is urging His Majesty Government to use its influence to bring about an adequate representation upon the S Canal Company of all classes of British sb | ping which make use of the canal. There is - strong feeling among British shipowners t the "Mistress of the Seas" - should also mistress of the Suez Canal. Over four thousand vessels pass yearly through the Canal, and annual tonnage is considerably over thirty million tons, the British percentage being 68 | While in Parliamentary circles there is improvement for a more adequate representation the existing Canal Committee, in circles a proposal to make a new canal is receiving influential support. The contention that the present canal does not supply Brit requirements, and the shipowners pay highly for inadequate accommodation. The maximum draught of water allowed for vessels using the canal is 27 feet-insufficient for larger British warships. Its breadth—121 5in.-does not allow of very large ships making their way under steam, but needs the service of u gs. The canal cost £24,000,000 to construct and enlarge.

div.head: CHEAPER CONSTRUCTION.
div.p: It has been computed that the construction of a far more commodious water way worthy British engineers and England's immense interest in the object would not in these days cost as much as the present canal. It is believed that as the public would entertain no doubt success when the work was undertaken by eminent British engineers and contractors there could be no financial difficulty, nor an necessity of a Government guarantee in the days when it is hard to find safe investment for superabundant capital. According to one survey already made a better line for part the distance than that of the present can might be found, and that is a point which will have to be fully considered.

No doubt is entertained by those who wish to construct a new waterway, about a Britis canal being made to suit British requirement in the present, and England's greater needs in the future, and to make a larger return on the capital expended This is proved by the existing canal, upon which much money was wasted. The only serious objection arises from the fact that the British Government hold £4,000,000 (now valued at £32,000 000 stock of the present canal, the value of which would be depreciated by the competition. *

div.head: BRITISH ROUTE TO ENGLAND.
div.p: This is a consideration of some importance but it is contended that it cannot outweigh the immense advantages of having communications -with India entirely in British hands. In commercial circles in the City and the great shipping ports in the provinces it is believed that there would probably be traffic enough for both canals Even among shipowners and merchants who are in favour of a new caval, there are those who are asking : -"How would the scheme, if adopted, affect the "Entente Cordiale.'" .

There are those still living who remember the origin and early history of the Suez Canal under the days when France, then under the influence of the Napoleonic "legend," was ready co go to war literally with Europe in defence of imaginary rights in Egypt. Another generation, however, has sprung up unconscious of those times, and quite unaware how irreconcilble were the views of the French politicians of a long bygone day with the generally received notions of Englishmen on the subject..

When the Crimean · and Franco-Austrian ars had enormously exalted the prestige of France, to some extent at the expense of England, a concession was granted M. de Lesseps (virtually France) which would have been an intolerable menace and danger to England. The original concession was not merely the right to construct the canal, but one possess a slice of Egypt commanding the whole course of the canal and which would very soon have become French territory. It was 18 & most effectual anti-English measure that M. de Lesseps regarded the Suez Canal, "a pear to pierce the armour of England," as he once called it. And in that light, according to history, it was received in France,

div.head: MALTA FEVER
div.p: In view of the fact that Malta fever is becoming a not infrequent disease in Egypt, it is worth noting that a further report of the commission appointed by the Admiralty, the War Office, and the Civil Government of Malta for the investigation of Malta or Mediterranean ever has just appeared. In this Staff-Surgeon E. A. Shaw details experiments relating to various possible paths of infection by the micro-organism of the disease Major W. H. Horrocha supplies a valuable contribution on outbreaks of the fever in Gibraltar and the general question of infection by goats. The pinion is expressed that the rapid disappear. mice of Mediterranean fever from the Rock, which commenced in 1885, was intimately Associated with the greatly-lessened important on of goats from Malta, At the present time ne goat-keepers introduce Spanish goats, but, the interests of the public health, it is held that notwithstanding the healthy conditions now prevailing, all goats brought to Gibraltár could be quarantined until examinations of the Lord have shown them to be free from infection.

div.head: EX-MAYOR CRUMBO RECOMMENDS PE-RU-NA
div.p: "My Endorsement of Pe-ru-na is Based on its Merits - Ed Crumbo.

ED. CRUMBO Ex-Mayor of New Albany, Ind., written from 511 E. Oak street: "My endorsement of Peruna is based on its merits. If a man is sick he looks anxiously for something which will cure him and Perunaq will do the work. "I know that it will cure catarrh of the head or stomach, indigestion, headache and any weary or sick feeling. "It is bound to help anyone, if used according to directions. "I also know dozens of men who speak in the highest terms of Peruna and have yet to hear of anyone being disappointed in it." Mr. Crumbo, in a ;ater letter, dated Aug 25, 1904, says: "My health is good, at present, but if I should have to take any more medicine I will fall back on Peruna"

div.head: PROSPECTUS.
div.p: This Company has been formed for the purposes set forth in its Memorandum of Association and in particular to manufacture, deal in, sell and let on hire motor cars and motor cabs and also to acquire and take over from the Vendor a9 & going concern the garage business carried on at Cairo by Mr. Christos Loukaitis. ..
The Company will have a spacious garage and workshops well furnished with tools for the repair, manufacture and alteration of motor cars

The Vendor Mr. Loukaitis has been appointed General Manager of the Company for a period of five years from the incorporation of the Company at a salary of £600 per annum and he is bound not to engage in any business in Egypt of a nature calculated to compete with that of the Company.

The property included in the sale comprises the. Vendor's business, hig garage at Cairo held on lease for an unexpired term of five years (dating from 20th March 1906) at the moderate annual rental of £180 and the full benefit of all pending contracts and engagements and subject to all pending trade contracts and engagements.

The purchase price has been fixed at £2500 or such legs sum as shall be certified by two valuers one to be appointed by the Vendor and the other by the Company or their umpire to be the true value of the property to be sold.
The whole of the purchase price viz: £2000 will be satisfied by the allotment to the Vendors or his nominees of 625 fully paid up ordinary shares of £4 each in the Capital of the Company.

The balance of 5000 Ordinary Shares after deduction of the 625 which are to be issued as fully paid to the Vendor, has been underwritten by the Directors including the Vendor in the following proportions: H. H. Prince Aziz Pacha Hassan 4/60 tbs., Mr. T. N. Koressios 10/60ths., Mr. E. Manusardi 7/50ths., MrJS Gali 7/50ths., Mr. E. Buccianti 47/60ths., UrN. Chakour Bey 5'50ths. and Mr. C Loukaitis 10 50ths.
Of the 5000 Founders shares, 500 are reserved for allotment to subgèribers for ordinary shares in the proportion of one Founders share for every ten ordinary shares and the remainder

29,000 Founders shares are to be divided between the Founders of the Company and the Vendor, according to the Agreement dated 13th June 1906 and this as remuneration for the underwriting of the above 5000 Ordinary Shares
The minimum subscription on which the Directors may proceed to allotment is 10 percent of the shares offered.

The Contract for the sale of the business is dated the 1st August 1906, and made between the said Christus Loukaitis of the last part, all the above named Directors and the said Christos Loukaitis of the 2nd vart and Nechib Ayoub of Cairo As Trustee for the Company (then about to be registered) of the 3rd part

The above mentioned tuo contracts have been adopted by a further contract dated the 7th February 1907 and made between Theodor Nicolas Coresgy-Koression and Emile Manusard of Cairo both Directors of and on behalf of the Company of the 1st part and Christos Loukalt of Cairo being the vendor of the 2d part and Neghib Ayoub, Advocate of Cairo as trustee foi the Company of the 3rd part.

The Articles of Association provide that the qualification of every Director is to be the holding of shares or Stock of the Company of the nominal value of £ 200 and that a first Director may act before acquiring his qualification.

The Articles of Association also provide that the Directors shall be paid out of the funds of the Company by way of remuneration for their services the percentage of profits specified in the Company's Memorandum of Association and such further sums as shall from time to time be determined by the Company in General Meeting and that such percentage of profits and further sums (if any) shall be divided among them in bunch proportions and manner' as the Directors by agreement may determine and in default of such determination equally. They also provide that the remuneration of a Managing Director shall from time to time be Axed by the Directors or by the Company in General Meeting ang may be by way of salary or commission or participation in profits or by any or all of these methods and they also provide that if any Director being willing shall be called upon to perform extra services or to take any special exertions in going or residing abroad or otherwise for any of the purposes of the Company, the Company shall remunerate such Director either by a fixed pum or by a percentage of profits or otherwise as naay be determined by the Directors and such remuneration may be dither in addition to or in substitution to his share in the remuneration as herein before stated.
The preliminary expenses up to allotment for the incorporation of the Company are estimated at £600, the stamp duty is included in this amount and payable by the Company.
for Copies of the Memorandum and Articles of Association of the Company and of the above mentioned Contracts can be inspected at the Company's Office in Cairo at any time during business hours. is
A Copy of the Company's Memorandum of Association is printed on the back of this prospectus and forms part of it.

Application for shares should be made upon the form accompanying the prospectus and sent to the Company Bankers, the Cassa di Sconto e di Risparmio Cairo and Alexandria, together with a remittance for the amount of the deposit. Where no allotment is made the deposit will be returned in full and where the number of shares allotted is less than the number applied for, the balance of the deposit will be applied towards the remaining payments Failure to pay any future instalment on shares allotted when due will render previous payments liable to forfeiture
Prospectus and Forms of Application can be obtained at the Company's Office in Cairo and Alexandria. Dated Ciiro the 23rd day of February 1907.

div.p: La Municipalité met en adjudication les travaux de pavage en asphalte d'une partie 1, la Roe, Rosette.
Le cautionnement est fixé à L.E. 60 (soixante).
Le cahier des charges est déposé au bureau Technique où il peut être consulté par les intéressés tous les jours de 9 h: à midi, les jours fériés exceptés.

Les offres devront être adressées sous pli cacheté à Monsieur l'Administrateur de la municipalité avant le 25 Mars 1907. - Elles pourront également être déposées en cance de la Délégation le même jour à h. p.m.
L'enveloppe devra porter en outre la mention : "Soumission pour travaux d'asphaltage 'âne partie de la Terre Rosette."
Le cautionnement ou le reçu d'une banque, après les conditions du cahier des charges, devra être remis séparément au Service de
Comptabilité Générale avant l'ouverture 38 offres et au plus tard le 25 Mars 1907 midi. Toute offre.qai de remplit pas les condi ons oi dessus sera écartée.
L'Administrateur
(Signé) W. P. CHatawAY.
Alexandrie, le 9 Mars 1907.

div.head: BULLETIN DE LA BOURSE
div.p: (Aujourd'hui à midi et demie.)

La hausse du taux privé d'escompte de 4 7/8 A5%, accompagnée de la baisse du Consolide À 85 3/8 et de la rente à 95.92 a de nouveau paralysé notre marché. La plupart des grosses valeurs sont délaissées et offertes. En revanche plusieurs nouvelles émissions donnent lieu un mouvement plus ou moins 'actif. • De ce nombre sont Arditi, la Levico, le Ritz Hôtels, le fondateur Famous.

Pour cette dernière, les esprits réfléchis sont étonnés qu'elle se tienne à 4 1/2, tandis que l'action est au-dessous du pair. Il y a là une inconséquence flagrante : si la fondateur vaut ce qu'elle est cotée, l'action doit valoir par le fait même plus que le pair.
La Levico s'avance 19/32, sur la rumeur que le Conseil d'Administration a conclu une importante affaire de courtage.
La fondateur United s'avance à 9 3/8 et les Ritz à 2 8/16.
En hausse également les Ninkovich Hôtels à 28 3/4, la Delta Land - 3 7/8, la Nile Land A 28 /8, l'Ordinaire Khedivial Mail à 30 et le Crédit Franco-Égyptien à 6 1/32

Par contre, l'Agricole fléchit à 9 1/16, la National Bank à 27 5/8, la Daïra à 16, la Behra á 40, la Building Lands á 5 5'8 et l'Union Foncière à 5 15,16, etc. · L'Allotement s'effondre a 3 1/16 et la Divi. dende Bière du Caire • 56.
La tendance générale demeure indécise.
Circulaire 1. De Vries et Boutigny
NOTES ET CRITIQUES
Le Caire, Mardi 12 Mars 1907

Le taux de l'escompte libre à Londres se maintient 24 7/8 pour cent. Stock Exchange, la Consolidé anglais a encore baissé hjer de 1/8 & 85 8/4. L'Unifiée est restée avariée à 102 1/4. La National Bank a gagné 1/8 À 27 8/4. L'Agricole est demeurée inchangée & 9 1/8, de même que la Daïra à 16 7/8 et la Deltalight à 11 1/4. .
A Paris, le Crédit Foncier Égyptien a reperda 4 franog á 746. La Banque d'Athènes a rétrogradé do 1 frano à 137.

Notre marché des valeurs a montré, ce matin, plan d'animation et d'activité s'bier ; mais la tendance n'en a pas moins persisté à rester lourde, sans être toutefois mauvaise. Nous traversons une période d'expectative très inté ressante, on 08 Bens qu'une dépression sérieuse nouvelle paraît rencontrer des obstacles presque insurmontables, alors qu'une bonne reprise pourrait se produire aisément, d'an joara l'autre; étant donnés, d'une part, des cours réellement bas, et d'autre part, une situation de plans qui ne saurait plus inspiré d'inquiétudes légitimes après le nettoyage salutaire de 'certaines positions à la hausse.

Dans le compartiment des Bing 709, la NA. tional a faibli a 27 11/16 et lAgricol. a 9.9 1/16. La Cassa di sconto s'est tassés à 233 l'action ancienne et à 280 la nouvelle ; la nouvelle émission a été traitée . 216. Le Comptoir Financier est revenu d/ 7 1/16-1/8. L'action Société Générale Egyptienne a été cotée 270 et la part 88.
Le Crédit Foncier s'est alourdi à 745. La Nile Land a été mieux tenge å 23 1/3. L'Enterprise and Development a ré rogredé à 11 1/4. L'Allotement a fléchi à 8 1/8.

Los Bat Reprises Ium biliaires et Travaux, très mouvementées, ont été ramenée, au début do la séance, à 7 3/8 pour remonter vivement à 8 1/4 et altérer aux abords de 8. Beaucoup de transactions également sur la part de fondateur, qui a baissé un moment d 118 pour s'élever ensuite à 130 et terminer à 127,
L'Express Nile a eu aussi un très bon marché; l'action ancienne a avancé à 5 1/16-1/8; la nouvelle s'est maintenue à 4 5/8; la part a fini
146. L'Epargne Immobilière s'est tenue à 2 13/16 at sa part à 185.
Les actions de capital Brux -da Caire opt faibli à 121-122 et les Jouissances à 275. 3!
Dans le groupe des valeurs hôtelière, les Nangovich ont recalé à 28-28 1/16, les Egyptian & 18 et les Excelsior 3 15/16 4.

Parmi les petites valer., la Delta Land. s'est raffermie à 3 15/16 ; on s'attend, paraît il, à an movement sar ce titre. Les New Zyprian sont revenus à 24 mb. 7 1/2, les Hooker å! 1 1/16, los Abdy à 1 1/8 et les Oasis d 0 7/8. L78 Patates sont restés à 2 1/4 at leor part à 22 8/4. Les parts de fondateur Egyptian Land Investment and Building, très recherchées, ont atteint £ 4 1/2.
Dans la séance qu'il a tende hier, le conseil d'administration de la National Bank of Egypt a doodle de fixer à £ 20 le taux de la nouvelle émission de 50,000 actions.

L'assemblée générale extraordinaire des actionnaires appelée à approuver la transformation de cet établissement de crédit en Banque d'Etat, l'augmentation de capital social, ainsi que les modifications y relatives apportées aux Statuette, sera con vogado 100888 amment.
On annonce de Londres la réduction incessante de l'assemblée générale extraordinaire de la Delta Land Co. appelée à approuver les arran. gomonts importante intervenus récemment au Caire.

L'entrée de M. Raphaël Saares dans le conseil d'administration peut être actuellement sõnaidérée comme certaine, les négociations en ofpra entre la Compagnie et la maison Soares ayant définitivement abouti.
L'assemblée générale ordinaire de la New Egyptian Co., tende samedi passé à Londres, a approuvé à l'unanimité le rapport des administrateurs, ainsi que les comptes de l'exercice Google.
Dans son allocution, le président de l'assemblée s renouvelé la declaration, déjà traité

dans le rapport, suivant laquelle un dividende -substantiel serait réparti aux actionnaires ! aussitôt après les négociations pendantes pour la vente d'âne des propriétés de la Com. pagnie auraient abouti.
L'assemblée générale ordinaire de la Cassa di Sconto e di Risparmio, qui devait se tenir avant-hier au siège social à Alexandrie, a 68 renvoyée, faute de quorum, ao dimanche 17 Mars courant.

- Les actionnaires de la Cairo Suburban Building Lands Co. sontheon vossen agremblée générale ordinaire au Caire pour le 27 Mars grant, à 3 h. 30 p.m., dans les baresıx de la Socié & Gánérale Bgyptiende pour l'Agrioultaro et le Commerce. A l'ordre du jour: rapport | 1g . conseil et approbation des comptes de l'exercice. 1916 ; examen des affaires de la Société, eto.
La Société d'Entreprises Immobilières et de Travaux tran-féré ses borosak dans l'immeuble Alti boy, 24 rue El Maghraby (au-dessus de l'Agence du Lloyd Autrichien).
Toutes signalisations intéressant ladite Société doivent être adressées au nouveau bureau.

div.head: TO OUR VISITORS
div.p: The Egyptian Gazette has much pleasure in presenting to its subscribers the accompanying description of some of the many interesting routes by which they may travel homewards. Great care has been taken to arrange them as accurately and concisely as possible, and it will be found that none of them are fraught with difficulty. In choosing the route home there are several things to be considered. To begin with there is the difference in climate between Egypt and the various points at which you may arrive in Europe.

This depends partly upon the month in which you leave Egypt, for Cairo in January may be a little warmer than the Riviera and possibly not so warm as Sicily, but in March it will be warmer than Rome, and more uniformly warm than many other places in Europe. Many people leave Egypt far too early in the year, for as a rule the weather in April and May is perfect. The warmest place to go to on leaving Egypt is Sicily.

Some will want to take into consideration the number of days to be spent at sea, and we therefore subjoin a list shewing the time occupied on each of the various routes between Egypt and the Continent of Europe.
They are as follows:—
The long sea routes—from Port Said or Alexandria to Plymouth, Southhampton, London or Liverpool—occupy about 14 days. The short ones are as follows:—

The steamers of the P.& O., the Egyptian Mail S.S,. Co., North German Lloyd, Orient, and Messageries Maritimes are the largest. The Anchor, British India, Bibby and Henderson Lines are also excellent, and their steamers are largely patronised by travellers to Egypt.
As regards the train journeys from Cairo, the shortest is that to Alexandria, without change (3 hours). That to Port Said can now be made without change in 4 ½ hours.

The least expensive way to England is by the Moss, Papayanni, Prince, and Westcott lines of steamers from Alexandria to Liverpool. The German Levant line has also good steamers from Alexandria to Hamburg.

The quickest through Continental routes are by P.& O. Brindisi express from Port Said, by the Egyptian Mail S.S. Co., from Alexandria to Marseilles and the Austrian Lloyd Trieste Vienna express from Alexandria.

As regards heavy luggage, it must be borne in mind that very little luggage is allowed free on the railways of Europe, but there are several good and responsible forwarding agents in Egypt who undertake at a fixed charge to deliver packages to any address in Europe. The Egyptian Mail S.S. Co., have also made arrangements whereby luggage can be collected and sent to any address.

The quickest manner of getting to Europe from Port Said is undoubtedly by the fast Mail Steamers "Osiris" and "Isis” to Brindisi. One of these leaves Port Said every week, as soon as possible after receiving the Indian mails from the great liner arrived from Bombay.

These small but comfortable ships have enormously powerful engines, and attain a very high rate of speed. They are called the "Ferry Boats" having been specially built to carry the British mail from Port Said to Brindisi. If you are going straight through to England you will find the train waiting at Brindisi which will take you to Calais without changing. It has complete arrangements for sleeping and eating on board, and you should arrive in London on the fifth day from leaving Port Said.

div.head: SICILY.
div.p: The direct route to Sicily is by the Florio-Rubattino Co.'s steamers which leave Alexandria weekly for MESSINA, where one takes train to TAORMENA, one of the most charming and popular places on the island. Giardini is the station at which to alight, and the drive up to Taormina is most delightful, occupying about one hour. In and around the town is much to interest the visitor. The theatre is of Greek origin, but restored under the Romans. CATANIA is the starting place for the ascent of Etna, and here also is a fine Cathedral. The Greek, Roman, and Saracenic remains that are found all over the island, are an endless sources of pleasure. SYRACUSE has an interesting history, having been a Greek city, which was designed by Demosthenes in B.C. 413, and taken by the Romans in B.C. 212, when Archimedes was slain—his tomb is to be seen. The cathedral was once an ancient pagan temple. PALERMO, with about 300,000 inhabitants, is the capital of the Island, and enjoys a delightful climate. Much of interest is to be found in this fine city. The Palazzo Reale is of Saracenic origin and close to it the church of S. Giovannia degli Eremiti with its picturesque cloisters. The Cathedral, Museum, Botanic Gardens, Villa Giulia and Royal Park are also worth a visit.

div.head: CENTRAL ITALY.
div.p: The fine steamers of the North German Lloyd leave Alexandria every Wednesday during the season for Naples, the voyage being only 3 days.

NAPLES is also reached in 10 hours from Palermo by the Florio-Rubattino Co.'s steamers, which leave daily. One cannot approach Naples or leave it without wishing to explore some of its islands, besides the lovely places on its bay—Castellamare and Sorrento. The small steamer that takes you to Sorrento [you can drive too] will take you on to Capri.

From Naples to ROME is a train journey of but five hours. All who can will devote at least one week to visiting the many historical and interesting portions of the Eternal City, whose charms and beauties are too well-known to need comment here.

Leaving the Eternal City with much regret, a railway journey of five hours brings you to FLORENCE, where another week can well be spent admiring the City of Flowers and its surrounding country. In Florence itself the churches and galleries are of absorbing interest, whilst the local promenades and excursions should not be omitted. The Cascine is the most attractive and fashionable promenade in Florence, whilst the Viale dei Colli, one of the finest walks in Europe, opened 35 years ago, goes winding up through the hills a distance of four miles. The most delightful excursion outside Florence is that to Vallombrosa, with its Monastery 3,300 feet above the sea level. This is made first by ordinary train from Florence to St. Ellero, thence by cog-wheel railway to Saltino. The ascent through groves of oaks takes an hour, and most striking panoramas are unfolded to view.

PISA is easily reached from Florence in about 2 hours ; here there is a fine Cathedral and the Leaning Tower. A stay of at least one night should if possible be made in order to enjoy the view from the Campanile at sunset.

VIAREGGIO. One of the most delightful places on the Italian Riviera near Pisa and on the main line from Rome to Genoa. It is a very convenient half-way house between Egypt and England, and where living is reasonable and the air and surroundings exceptionally good.

div.head: NORTHERN ITALY
div.p: GENOA (La Superba).—The most picturesque and interesting city in Italy, with the record of having one of the lowest death averages of European cities and a phenomenally equable temperature—warm in winter and deliciously cool breezes from the surrounding mountains and the Mediterranean in summer.

The patriarchal home of Italy's most ancient nobility, whose palaces, gardens, and famous collections of statuary, frescoes, and paintings, are a constant delight to thousands of travellers who annually sojourn in Genoa. Then there are the superbly decorated medieval churches containing exquisite marble columns and historical paintings, and the incomparable Campo Santo filled with its wonderful tombs.
From Genoa to Milan is a matter of only three hours by rail.

MILAN is a good centre for Northern Italy before making the tour of the Lakes. The Cathedral is the principal attraction, with its beautiful windows illustrating the History of the Bible. The public gardens and the monumental cemetery are also worth a visit.

Between Bologna and Milan and only an hour and a half from Milan is SALSOMAGGIORE, a renowned health resort on account of its thermal springs, change trains at Borgo San Domino and in half-an-hour you are at Salsomaggiore.

div.head: NORTHERN ITALY (Continued) and The ITALIAN LAKES.
div.p: VENICE is a 5 hours journey by rail from Milan, and one of the most delightful places imaginable to pass a quiet stay. The total absence of vehicular traffic strikes one as very strange; no horse, cart, carriage or bicycle is to be seen, and yet there is the sound of life at every turn. The approach to Venice from the Adriatic is unlike that of any other sea port. The town seems to be gradually, like Aphrodite, born of the sea. No hills behind, no stretches of rock, but first the tops of Campaniles appear above the horizon, then slowly the whole glittering town rises like a fairy mirage out of the calm lagoon.
Going northwards from Milan you make the tour of the beautiful Italian lakes.
COMO, the birthplace of the younger Pliny, is reached in one-and-a-quarter hours by train by way of Monza.

Boats leave Como frequently for the other towns on the lake, which is very beautiful, and the scenery on either side going up the lake is most enchanting. CERNOBBIO is a charming spot; then come Tremezzo, Cadenabbia, and Menaggio with the prettily-situated town of Bellaggio opposite. The walk from Tremezzo along the shore of the lake to Menaggio is most enjoyable. A steam tram runs from Menaggio to Porlezza on Lake Lugano in three-quarters of an hour, then steamer to Lugano in two-and-three-quarter hours.

div.head: SWITZERLAND.
div.p: Switzerland, the heart of Europe, has been described as "A cluster of delights and grandeurs."

LUGANO is some 20 miles from Como and reached by train in one-and-a-half hours. It has a population of 10,000 people and is charmingly situated on the Lake of Lugano, amidst lovely Italian scenery. Around it rise M. San Salvatore, M. de Caprino.and M. Generoso.

LOCARNO may be reached by rail from Bellinzona in forty minutes. This pretty town, situated at the top of Lake Maggiore, has a mild climate and is an excellent winter resort. The church Madonna del Sasso, situated above the town, is worth a visit, as it contains interesting paintings, "Entombment," by Ciseri, and 'Tho Flight into Egypt,” by Bramantion.
LUCERNE—A striking picture on the Lake of Lucerne facing the Rigi and Pilatus and the snow-clad Alps.
In and around the town the walks are charming, and the excursions to be made from Lucerne by boat, rail, etc., are very numerous.

The Lake of Lucerne abounds in delightful excursions, those to the Rigi, Pilatus, Burgenstock and Sonnenberg needing a special visit each. Other excursions on the lake can be made by steamer, and the ever-changing scenery on the trip from Lucerne, to Fluelen is a source of delight to the lover of nature.

BRUNNEN, charmingly situated on the most beautiful part of the Lake of Lucerne, commands magnificent views of lake and mountain scenery. Along the Lake of Uri from Brunnen to Fluelen runs the famous Axentrasse.

THUN (on the Lake of Thun) half an hour from Berne and one hour from Interlaken. Quiet and quaint; sheltered from winds; just the place to rest and recuperate. Beautiful walks, through woods, and along the lake shore. Kursaal, Concernts, Casino, Races, Tennis, Boating, etc.

THE BERNESE OBERHAND. – INTERLAKEN, a favourite summer resort and the best centre for making excursions in the Oberland, abounding in fine walks and views. There is a magnificent view of the Jungfrau from the Hoheweg, a fine avenue of walnut trees, the chief resort of visitors. Interlaken is also not far from the famous waterfalls, Giessbach, Trummelbath and Staubbach. Then also the glaciers of Grindelwald and view from Murren and the Schynige Platte are sights not to be missed.

CHATEAU D'OEX. 3,500 ft above the sea on the new Electric Railway between Montreux and Interlaken, surrounded by magnificent scenery, with pure dry air. Much frequented by English people in Summer and Winter.

ZURICH on the Gothard route. Direct communication with Northern Europe. Largest town in Switzerland, beautifully-situated on the lake of Zurich. Theatres. Big Concern Halls. Boating on the lake. Excellent schools. The National Museum.

div.head: GREECE and IONIAN ISLES.
div.p: Many people visit Greece after wintering in Egypt, as it is so easily reached from Alexandria ; the climate in April is charming. The best steamers are those of the Khedivial Mail Co. and the Russian Steam Navigation Co.

If possible tourists should arrange to be in Athens for the Orthodox Easter in order to witness the Good Friday and Easter Eve ceremonies, and to be present at the dancing on the Easter Tuesday festival held at Megara for which a special train is run from Athens.
It is worth while to spend a few days in CORFU on account of the beauty of the scenery. There is also good snipe and quail shooting to be had.

div.head: SALSOMAGGIORE (Italy.)
div.p: A pleasantly situated village lying in the valley between Piacenza and Parma, rapidly becoming famous for its waters, which are very rich in bromine and iodine and the richest in the world in lithium, strontium, and ichthyol, and have been successfully used in the treatment of scrofula, rheumatism, tuberculous affections, ladies complaints, etc.

Les personnes qui connaissent les
Pilules du Docteur DEHAUT de Paris

n'hésitent pas à se purger, quand elles en ont besoin. Elles ne craignent ni le dégoût ni la fatigue, parce que, à l'opposé des autres purgatifs, celui-ci n'opère bien que lorsqu'il est pris avec de bons aliments et des boissons fortifiantes, telles que vin, café, thé. Chacun choisit, pour se purger, l'heure et le repas qui lui conviennent le mieux, selon ses occupations. La fatigue de la purgation étant annulée par l'effet de la bonne alimentation, on se décide aisément à recommencer autant de fois que cela est nécessaire.

div.head: Supplement Commercial et Financier DE " L'EGYPTIAN GAZETTE"
div.p: Le Supplément Commercial et Financier TB egyptian Gazette" paraît chaque Samedi midi, de façon pouvoir être expédié par le paquebot autrichien. Il contient des revues complètes et impartiales de coton, des graines de coton, et du marché des valeurs ; les dernières statistiques jango's la veille de sa publi cation : des tableaux des flnetostions de la place et les copies des déployée officielles envoyée la Liverpool Cotton Association, oto ste L'abonnement pour une année en Egypte soate 1 LR y compris les frais de poste ; pour Stranger 10 PT. de port ea sas.

div.head:

Pills for the Liver & Kidneys
div.p: are an unfailing and reliable remedy for diseases of these important organs, gout, rheumatism, gravel pains in the back and kindred ailments (acquired or constitutional). Sold by principal Chemists, not in loose quantities, but only in boxes, price 2s. 3d bearing the British Government Stamp with the words "Eugene Le Clerc" impressed thereon to protect the public from fraud.
